section.title: Introduction
section.para: Event handlers are optional system commands (scripts or executables) that are run whenever a host or service state change occurs.
An obvious use for event handlers is the ability for Nagios to proactively fix problems before anyone is notified. Some other uses for event handlers include:

listitem.para: Entering a trouble ticket into a helpdesk system
Logging event information to a database

important.para: Cycling power on a host that is experiencing problems with an automated script should not be implemented lightly. Consider the consequences of this carefully before implementing automatic reboots. :-)

section.title: When Are Event Handlers Executed?
section.para: Event handlers are executed when a service or host:

listitem.para: Is in a SOFT problem state
Initially goes into a HARD problem state
Initially recovers from a SOFT or HARD problem state

section.para: SOFT and HARD states are described in detail here .

section.title: Event Handler Types
section.para: There are different types of optional event handlers that you can define to handle host and state changes:

Global host and service event handlers are run for every host or service state change that occurs, immediately prior to any host- or service-specific event handler that may be run. You can specify global event handler commands by using the global_host_event_handler and global_service_event_handler options in your main configuration file.

Individual hosts and services can have their own event handler command that should be run to handle state changes. You can specify an event handler that should be run by using the event_handler directive in your host and service definitions. These host- and service-specific event handlers are executed immediately after the (optional) global host or service event handler is executed.

section.title: Enabling Event Handlers
section.para: Event handlers can be enabled or disabled on a program-wide basis by using the enable_event_handlers in your main configuration file.

Host- and service-specific event handlers can be enabled or disabled by using the event_handler_enabled directive in your host and service definitions. Host- and service-specific event handlers will not be executed if the global enable_event_handlers option is disabled.

section.title: Event Handler Execution Order
section.para: As already mentioned, global host and service event handlers are executed immediately before host- or service-specific event handlers.
Event handlers are executed for HARD problem and recovery states immediately after notifications are sent out.

section.title: Writing Event Handler Commands
section.para: Event handler commands will likely be shell or perl scripts, but they can be any type of executable that can run from a command prompt. At a minimum, the scripts should take the following macros as arguments:
For Services: $SERVICESTATE$, $SERVICESTATETYPE$, $SERVICEATTEMPT$For Hosts: $HOSTSTATE$, $HOSTSTATETYPE$, $HOSTATTEMPT$

The scripts should examine the values of the arguments passed to it and take any necessary action based upon those values. The best way to understand how event handlers work is to see an example. Lucky for you, one is provided below.

tip.para: Additional sample event handler scripts can be found in the contrib/eventhandlers/ subdirectory of the Nagios distribution. Some of these sample scripts demonstrate the use of external commands to implement a redundant and distributed monitoring environments.

section.title: Permissions For Event Handler Commands
section.para: Event handler commands will normally execute with the same permissions as the user under which Nagios is running on your machine. This can present a problem if you want to write an event handler that restarts system services, as root privileges are generally required to do these sorts of tasks.

Ideally you should evaluate the types of event handlers you will be implementing and grant just enough permissions to the Nagios user for executing the necessary system commands. You might want to try using sudo to accomplish this.

section.title: Service Event Handler Example
section.para: The example below assumes that you are monitoring the &protocol-http; server on the local machine and have specified restart-httpd as the event handler command for the &protocol-http; service definition. Also, I will be assuming that you have set the max_check_attempts option for the service to be a value of 4 or greater (i.e. the service is checked 4 times before it is considered to have a real problem). An abbreviated example service definition might look like this...
section.programlisting: define service{ host_name somehost service_description HTTP max_check_attempts 4 event_handler restart-httpd ... }

This prevents Nagios from continuously executing the script to restart the web server if the service remains in a HARD problem state. You don't want that. :-)
